captions.text:
00:11
COMM: As the Sakurajima volcano is Southern

Japan erupts a series of times, volcanic lightning
in the ash cloud is clearly visible. And phenomenon

that is rarely seen and not fully understood
by scientists.

00:37
COMM: Mark Szeglat is a photographer who specialises

in shooting volcanos. In his career he's climbed
over forty. Many of them several times. In

early march he was studying the Sakurajima
volcano in Japan, and witnessed several eruptions.

01:03
COMM: Volcanic lightning is rare to observe,

as it only usually occurs at large eruptions.
But this seems to be a hot spot where it can

01:16
COMM: The last major eruption of the volcano
occurred in 1914 when thirty-five people died.

01:25
COMM: But since 1955, it's been erupting almost

constantly, and experts worry that another
large eruption might be imminent.

comments.text:
Rare Footage Of Volcanic Lightning

 We upload a new incredible video every weekday. Subscribe to our YouTube 
channel so you don't miss out!
A VOLCANO explodes into life as it sprays burning hot ash high into the air 
- followed by a deafening shockwave. Shot by filmmaker Marc Szeglat, 47, 
this incredible footage shows the highly active Sakurajima volcano on the 
Japanese island of Kyushu. The German videographer was able to capture the 
rare phenomenon of volcanic lightning, as well as an explosive shockwave 
which rippled through the sky. Sakurajima, translated as Cherry Island, has 
been erupting on a regular basis since 1955 and is a constant danger to the 
nearby city of Kagoshima, which has a population of over 600,000.﻿

comments.text:
*Смотрите ! Интересно !*
*Вулканические молнии удалось снять в Японии (видео)*
17.03.2015 - 15:00
Немецкому фотографу Марку Сцеглату удалось запечатлеть на видео чрезвычайно 
редкое природное явление — вулканические молнии. Эти кадры были сняты на 
вулкане Сакурадзима в Японии.
К возникновению молний над извергающимся вулканом приводят как 
сейсмологические процессы, так и процессы, идущие в облаках при обычных 
грозах. Электрические заряды могут возникать за счёт пьезоэлектрических, 
трибоэлектрических и подобных явлений при разломах и подвижках горных 
пластов, сопровождающих извержение.﻿

comments.author: Pandapls

comments.text:
Volcanoes form over weaker areas in the crust and/or areas of high pressure 
buildup over time. The molten lava works its way up until the pressure 
overcomes the ability of the rocks/earth on top to keep it in the ground. 
That's the eruption. 
Also the process that produces "volcano lightning" has been theorized as to 
how it  happens (see other comment), but I'm not sure if it has been 
reproduced in a lab yet for confirmation.
